Mr. MCLELAN.—The hon. gentleman has made this important admission—that the de- legates only asked for three millions, and he says that this was the sum asked for in 1862. In 1862 it was supposed that that sum would build the entire road, but recent surveys have demonstrated the impossibility of that, and there is therefore an important distinction be- tween the position of the delegates and their predecessors. In view of the fact that such a sum had been shown insufﬁcient, the delegates were in duty bound to have asked for a larger guaranty.
